Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 09:29AM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi, it's really okay to tell the doctors - I can't take steriods so they changed what I was being given to accommodate my needs, it was simple.  My oncologist says, there's always other choices, so don't worry.  this is your body and if someone wants to force you to do something you just don't feel is right, tell them it's not appropriate to not listen to you.  and, If you don't get nauseous, you don't need drugs.  You may have a road in front of you, so don't disappear, you are always in charge - see if these people can be your team, and if not, get a better team, you deserve it.
Posts.Title: anyone NOT take their pills MJ6266 stateofgrace33

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 10:41PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi, thanks so much for you spot-on description of what you are going thru - I too am searching for a quality of life through all the hideous, and what I call cruel treatments.  The cure, for me, has been extremely painful and destructive and I often wonder if I will have space when I'll feel better or is this watch it's going to be like until I finally die...  I talk to my onc about it though and we've changed my treatment a lot and right now I have a month off from most chemicals.  I needed a break.  What's happening is that I'm just in a recovery phase and very fatigued.  I think I'd be a lot worse if I wasn't taking a break from chemicals. lots and lots and lots of understanding and caring Christine

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 01:53PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Thanks Tabbygirl, I ended up with a great anesthesiologist who used short-term anesthesia and I awoke with no problems for the first time.  He really listened and believed my reports of sensitivity.  You know, it only takes a little listening to do the right thing, and I think the choice of doctor determines if they will listen.  I went to a private surgery center so I had time to consult. thanks for writing and supporting me. Christine
Posts.Title: Anyone Had Lumpect w/out Rads Afterwards? stateofgrace33 stateofgrace33

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 03:37PM stateofgrace33 wrote: I too have a clean breast but the bone mets persist, although the onc believes they are less (and my symptoms are better).  My cancer markers show more cancer activity, yet I'm feeling better is some ways.  Like others I am on Tamoxifen and zometa.  I'm hoping they will slow down the mets (onc thniks they will).  I did radiation before b reast surgery because the mets were in a dangerous spot on my spine, and the radiation really helped. My question to my doctor, because of what I've read in studies, is that some of the mets do not respond to the type of treatment I was receiving for my breast (estrogen positive) and that the mets could actually need different type of treatment.  the only way to do it is to biopsy some of the mets.  If they are on the spine, it can be too dangerous.  But I still want to check this path as I'd like to life a few more years! hope this info is helpful.
Posts.Title: How many of us have mets but clean breast vivo Roxanne1

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 12:32PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Thanks for the replies everyone, taking the time is a gift!, I did have the surgery a couple of days ago and the anesthesiologist really listened to my concerns about how severe the anesthesia has been in the past.  I did an outpatient procedure at a private surgery center where my surgeon had all her staff around her and her crew was great.  This time I did not have a reaction and was amazed.  They said they gave me short acting anesthesia and kept giving it throughout the 3 1/2 hour surgery.  They woke me right away.  They explained to me that when you do the long-acting type, they wake you but allow you to go back to sleep and you are usually in the hospital.  So, in a way, you still have so much of the anesthesia active in your system after surgery with long-acting type.  Well I think this made the difference for me because right after I awoke, I did not feel the anesthesia "feeling" at all, and I did not seize or feel that profound inability to fully awaken.   I don't know if you can use this type of anesthesia for all surgeries but if I ever need surgery again I am hoping they can use this type. I am still wondering though if anyone decided not to do radiation after a lumpectomy or mastectomy? thanks again! love,Christine
Posts.Title: Anyone Had Lumpect w/out Rads Afterwards? stateofgrace33 stateofgrace33

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 01:50PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Dear Nana, I can't remember, did I tell you a 3 x the average amount of Glutathione (an amino acid - see bottle for daily dose) will clear out the residue of anesthesia?  Even if it's been a while, it stays in fat tissue.  Alot of people are tire for a long time and it'll really help after surgery.   I'm an herbalist and holistic nutritionist and I'm not trying to give official advice, but I've annecdotally seen many, many people benefit from it. much love Chrisitne

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 05:18PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi,  I can see you gotten a lot of feedback, just one more thing...... as women we are often talked out of our intuition or told to be comfortable with something we are not comfortable with.  It's not a lot of trouble to get a second opinion, even if it's just to have a better rapport with your Doctor.  My surgeon kisses me (a woman) on the head at each visit and all her staff hugs and are incredibly kind.  I trust them - and it's my life, my body and I only want people to really key into me to help me with such life and death stuff. Your doc sounds scattered - you are probably not the only one who is having problems. I changed my oncologist because the first one was like a drill sargent and spoke so fast that I couldn't understand her....  She lasted 2 visits. love to you, be in the best hands you can. Christine
Posts.Title: Need some help understanding.... enthused stateofgrace33

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 06:52PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi, I was told I had a breast infection - this went on for a year and by the time I got fed up I already had Stage IV - I'll never put off a second opinion again - Drs being casual about breast cancer is just stupid and the doctors should know better in what we know about breast cancer in this day and age! go get it checked by someone who is no just calling it in.... love
Posts.Title: Age Discrimination. ACK! Minny DJ64

Posts.Content: May 22, 2009 11:20PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi, I tracked my pain levels over the last 7 months and I need Zometa at about 3 1/2 weeks.  A few days before the 30 day mark, I start having a lot of pain.  My caregiver also tracked it as well and said it was like clockwork.  We have enough pain without "waiting" to see if it happens again.  Go back to what works and trust that for yourself - it may just be how your body works.  You may have to argue with the doctor, but it's worth it so you don't have to suffer as much.  We need a quality of life - it's so important.  toughing it out is not necessary..... much love Christine
Posts.Title: How often do you get Zometa infusion? meima-Bev marieibrahim

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 01:30PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi Cathleen, I don't think they usuallly do a bone marrow test but will want to put on something for the mets.  I'm on Zometa and did several courses of chemo and Avastin.  It helped tremendously but caused extreme side effects.  but I tend to overreact to meds and chemicals. I'm stable right now because of the regime I was on.  Sounds like your onc knows what they are doing.  It is the most recent standard of care that can have good results for people.   This site has great articles for bone mets.  After I did my research, I could see my onc was following the most recent treatments and that helped me to be willing to do them. I hope this gives you a bit of info. good luck and I hope you find a treatment that works for you. love Christine
Posts.Title: Bone Mets CathleenP Jan50

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 06:50PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi makingway... thanks for addressing what I said with all you are going through right now....  I have mets to the bone (femurs, pelvis, ribs, spine) but they are much less after rads and chemo.  I had 2 spots of nodes show initially and now the PET SCAN, CT shows nothing in the nodes or the breast.  But like a lot of women are mentioning, the testing isn't perfect and I don't know what they will actually find when they get in there - and I sympathize with the surgeon wanting to get all the cancer.  My surgery is next week and I'm spending the weekend talking to those closest to me to help me find an answer that feels good before I agree to the surgery because I just found out she wants to take more breast tissue that she originally thought....  Don't be afraid of your surgeon even if she is doing it pro bono, because obviously she or he must be very generous and compassionate to do the surgery in that type of case.  Find out if they will listen to your fears because they should.... I wish you so many blessings as you navigate this difficult time - it's so hard, but we will all support you in love and kindness! love Christine
Posts.Title: Refuse To Do Surgery makingway nelia48

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2009 05:27PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Yes, get another doc - he put you through a lot of suffering and didn't consider how devastating it was to you.  Any doctor who writes you off will continue with that behavior -  You should never, never suffer like that again. My doc listens to everything I say and does everything she can to stop my suffering - this is how it should be - cancer is so terrible a disease, our docs should not create more problems. I'm sorry he promoted you to doubt in any way.  You are never crazy - you just have sincere questions and when they aren't answered fully, that just means there is more of a need for inquiry.... love christine
Posts.Title: I need answers about Doxil, Avastin & Taxotere very sick. dfleaman luvtotravel

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 06:31PM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi makingway, I'm at the same place as you are with all the treatments - I have stage IV and I don't know how long I'm going to live, but I've reacted to all the treatments and am living with lots of side effects.  I really want some quality of life and most of the treatments take that away.  I'm scheduled for a surgery and am having big time second thoughts because I too have been doing a lot of research....  I think all of our decisions are fraught with doubt because their aren't great answers out there.  I'm sorry you are going through what you are, but I wouldn't do something you are not comfortable with - and a second opinion is always helpful....    Drs are afraid to be sued as well - maybe that's coloring her response, or maybe she wants you to be a cancer free as possible --but then again, there may be another surgeon out there with better surgical technique or can find another possibility for you. love to hear what you decide as my current decision in the making is difficult and hearing what happens to you may help me and others like us much love to you Christine
Posts.Title: Refuse To Do Surgery makingway nelia48

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2009 02:16AM stateofgrace33 wrote: Dear PJB - if you read the pros/cons literature on Avastin- it has tons of side effects for too many people -- more than most meds.  I've read articles about it being questioned about whether it was put on the market too soon and whether it should be taken off  - it does however, get rid of the blood flow to tumors (helped me) But I have terrible neuropathy from being on it only for 6 weeks.....   Personally, I wouldn't go back on it as I'm a creative person and my hands hurt to do much of anything ..... I think if I would have stayed on it longer, my neuropathy would have just got worse and worse, and for some it's permanent..... bottom line, is so many of these meds have terribly cruel side effects.  I ask my onc so many questions about meds because there's always this idea that "only some people get side effects" and "you'll probably be okay"  -  At this point, I don't believe any of it since most treatments have caused terrible side effects.    and then there's the other side - how much are you willing to do to stay alive - and balanced with your quality of life?  No straight forward answers there.... Just know you are not alone and know you probably could not have prevented your nose issue.  Because if it was in our control, of course we would have done something!!! much love to you Christine
Posts.Title: Leave it to me to get a rare side effect PJB PJB

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 11:05AM stateofgrace33 wrote: Hi, yes, I started out with hypercalcemia which landed me into the emergency room.  It was a week later than I was diagnosed with stage IV with mets to bone.  I thought I was having recurring flu symptoms.... It happens if you are not getting treated and don't know you have cancer.....  But after I got zometa for a few months it greatly improved and I will continue on Zometa every month. hope this gives you hope you'll get better! warmly
